facts: The appellant filed a criminal complaint against the respondent for an offence under Section 138 of the Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881, alleging that a cheque issued for a property transaction was dishonored due to a stop payment instruction. The trial court acquitted the accused, finding that since the complainant failed to deliver vacant possession of the property, there was no legally enforceable debt.
charge: Offence under Section 138 of the Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881.
law_content: Section 138 NI Act: Deals with the penal consequences for dishonour of a cheque for insufficiency of funds to draw the amount, or when the amount exceeds the arrangement made with the bank. It requires the cheque to be presented within its validity period, returned unpaid, and notice to be given to the drawer, followed by failure to pay within 15 days of receipt of notice.
judgment: The appeal is dismissed. The trial court's finding that there was no legally enforceable debt due to non-delivery of vacant possession of the property, and thus the accused was not guilty under Section 138 of the NI Act, is upheld.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Quashing of proceedings in a Domestic Violence Case and stay of further proceedings. under Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court. This section allows the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. However, the Court referenced that a petition to quash proceedings in a Domestic Violence Case is not maintainable directly, as Section 29 of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005 provides an effective remedy.?
facts: The petitioners sought to quash proceedings in a Domestic Violence Case (DVC No. 37 of 2023) pending before a Magistrate Court. They also sought a stay on the proceedings. The case was filed by the wife against the petitioners, who are her husband and his family members.
charge: Quashing of proceedings in a Domestic Violence Case and stay of further proceedings.
law_content: Section 482 Cr.P.C. - Saving of inherent powers of High Court. This section allows the High Court to make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to any order under this Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice. However, the Court referenced that a petition to quash proceedings in a Domestic Violence Case is not maintainable directly, as Section 29 of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005 provides an effective remedy.
judgment: The High Court held that a petition to quash proceedings in a Domestic Violence Case is not maintainable under Section 482 Cr.P.C. The Court stated that Section 29 of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005, provides an efficacious remedy by way of an appeal against orders taking cognizance. The petitioners were granted liberty to avail this alternative remedy. The appearance of certain petitioners was also dispensed with except when required by the trial court.

facts: The petitioner is accused of marrying a minor girl, resulting in FIR No. 158/2023 for offences including rape of a minor and under the POCSO Act and PCM Act. The petitioner claims the marriage was consensual and the girl was of age, with conflicting evidence on her date of birth.

facts: The appellant was convicted for the offence under Section 3(i)(x) of the SCs/STs (POA) Act, 1989 and Section 323 of the IPC. The prosecution alleged that the appellant abused and beat the complainant, who belongs to an SC community. The complainant's version was supported by two witnesses.

question: What did the High Court decide regarding Seeking release from prison by challenging the warrant issued under Section 122(1)(b) of the Cr.P.C. for alleged breach of bond without due process. under Section 122(1)(b) Cr.P.C. - Allows for the arrest and detention of a person who has breached a bond for keeping the peace until the expiry of the bond period. Section 117 Cr.P.C. - Lays down the procedure for inquiry into the matter of security for keeping the peace or for good behaviour, which includes affording an opportunity of hearing to the person concerned and passing reasoned orders.?
facts: The petitioner, Amgoth Saroja, was detained in District Jail, Khammam, based on a warrant issued by the Executive Magistrate-cum-Tahsildar under Section 122(1)(b) of the Cr.P.C. for an alleged breach of a bond furnished under Section 110 of the Cr.P.C. The petitioner contended that the warrant was issued illegally without affording an opportunity of hearing or assigning reasons as required under Section 117 of the Cr.P.C.
charge: Seeking release from prison by challenging the warrant issued under Section 122(1)(b) of the Cr.P.C. for alleged breach of bond without due process.
law_content: Section 122(1)(b) Cr.P.C. - Allows for the arrest and detention of a person who has breached a bond for keeping the peace until the expiry of the bond period. Section 117 Cr.P.C. - Lays down the procedure for inquiry into the matter of security for keeping the peace or for good behaviour, which includes affording an opportunity of hearing to the person concerned and passing reasoned orders.
judgment: The Court held that a person cannot be detained under Section 122(1)(b) of the Cr.P.C. for breach of bond without a prior reasoned order under Section 117 Cr.P.C. Mere involvement in a crime does not constitute a breach of bond, and detention is not permissible without conviction or a proper inquiry demonstrating a breach. The petition was disposed of, implying the release of the petitioner or setting aside of the warrant.

This section specifies that if an offence under Section 138 is committed by a company, every person who, at the time the offence was committed, was in charge of, and was responsible to the company for the conduct of the business of the company, as well as the company, shall be deemed to be guilty of the offence and shall be liable to be proceeded against and punished accordingly.
